EngDesc: This threat sends a TCP packet that appears to be part of an existing valid connection with a NOOP sled in it. A NOOP sled is used by shellcode to insure that the injected code will execute. Unfortunately, there are many other reasons why a NOOP might appear in traffic. This threat utilized equivalent assembly instructions to the standard NOOP instruction.

This threat sends UDP packets with a payload filled with NOOP assembly instructions. This gets flagged on IDS systems as a possible shellcode injection attack. NOOPs are used as a sled to insure more probability for shellcode to execute. Unfortunately, NOOPs are also quite common in binary downloads from websites as well, causing many false positives.
